Your population multiplies exponentially if and the constant race to feed all of them is a challenge of itself. It's constant growth, all over, until you just can't take it anymore, the inefficiencies of your production cycles, however minute they were, are having a compounding effect and before you know it the healthy food production you thought you had plummets like a rock and it's late summer or later. By spring you've lost 10-15% of your population and you no longer have the manpower to work your system. Firewood production breaks down, there's nobody gathering new logs, fishermen are fiddling around but not catching anything - they're freezing to death because the hunters have stopped gathering leathers and your tailor, what tailor? plucky fishermen, the odd gatherer, the priest, they're holding on. You shut down the mines, markets are down to one vendor, throw everyone at food production but it's too late, you're out of firewood and winter is coming. You're doomed. Esc, new game hit the new seed button a few times and off you go again.  Yes, it's brutal but it's also fantastically good.

If you're reading this, it's safe to assume that you have an Internet-capable device with all of the modern comforts that typically implies. But what if you didn't? What if you were forced out of civilization as you know it, to live in the wilderness? How do you think you'd fare? Banished asks those questions, opening with a dozen or so outcasts seeking to make their way in the wilderness. It's a humble setup, but the game is masterfully constructed with dozens of interlocking mechanics--the perfect foundation for a stinging emergent narrative and a focus on empathy in the face of a Malthusian world.  People, more than anything else, are your vital resource. They need homes, food, decent clothes, tools, emotional support, medicine, and more. Every mechanic, every building you can place, and everything else you can do relates back to that central theme of survival. If you can't gather enough food, your people die. If they're stuck outside for too long, or don't have warm clothing, they die. Each time you fail as their leader, you're reminded of the loss with a grating sound and a yellow gravestone. These serve as a one-two punch to punish you for failure because losing citizens makes it that much harder to keep up the resource flow. One fewer worker means you can't gather food, stone, wood, or anything else as quickly. When children die, it's even worse, though you likely won't know it for some time. As your population ages, you eventually lose more than a few citizens to old age, and the best way to replace them is to give your younger citizens houses in the hopes that they'll reproduce and bolster your future numbers.While the process of survival is never-ending, holding out against the elements amid the hostility of the untamed natural world is a small but powerful personal victory. Villagers have names; they're born, grow up, and eventually die under your intense supervision. Banished reinforces the human drama with its brutal difficulty and negative feedback loops. It's fertile soil for some of the most remarkable emergent storytelling around. With relatively few, well-designed mechanics, the game weaves a powerful tale of empathy and desperation and is a high-water mark for narrative elements that mutually reinforce mechanics. Even better, this is a very human story divorced from the Western tropes common in the loosely imperialistic messages of other, similar games. It's just you, your people, and their strong desire to live.

This isn't like Civilization or the Sims where you can mindlessly build, buy, and spend to your hearts content. Banished requires thoughtfulness, planning, and strategy to make a successful city. Extremely addicting and definitely satisfying when your citizens are thriving.

I quite like city builders and especially if they're not always modern ones. This city builder is... well... I'd probably go as far as calling it 'cute'. :-)  I quite like the combination of survival city building and the fact, that it has trade as a major factor that could become a game changer at some stage during your many hours of growth and then sudden tragedy (the black death is lurking and suddenly all your blacksmiths died...!).   The learning curve I found quite hard, my first few games (I usually start playing standard game settings) I couldn't get my village to run without everyone dying either of starvation, cold or weird accidents (yes, tree can fall on your villagers). The graphics is neat and distinguishes - mainly because of the setting - quite from modern city builders which really gives it a good feel.   There are a few things I would have loved to see improved though.  - more buildings. It's quite interesting that despite all other city builders doing it differently, here all buildings are available from the start. However after some time it gets quite boring as you're basically building the same old all over the place. More variety would have been nice. - resources. After a while, all my mountains were plastered with iron and coal mines. Once a mine has been stripped of coal, you can't just change to iron. If one resource has been stripped, the other resource has been stripped too. The counter basically counts for all resources together. Eventually, you will run out of resources. Keeping the map running is difficult then, because tools need iron, without iron mines you have to rely on the trade boats, eventually with bigger cities, the trade boat with tools won't come often enough. - trade. Sometimes trade just doesn't make sense. I.e. some items could not be traded for certain other items. If that would be random I could understand (as in trader has requests too), but I remember trying each time and it was the same goods I wanted to trade-in that the trader didn't want. Rather odd. - Stone quarries are quite big and once they've run out of stone, nothing can be done with them. So you'll also start plastering big massive holes into your area which then can't be used anymore at all. If at the beginning you put one of those stone quarries into the wrong spot that will block your expansion, then you basically screwed up your hole game.  But these problems are small compared to the fun I had with the game. Certainly something to be recommended. I hope at some stage it will get some expansions or DLCs or something to extend the content a bit. Multiplayer would be great - a feature often requested but rarely implemented. :-)

This game is simply incredible, considering it was developed by 1 guy. The reviewers complaining about lack of content miss the point - and challenge - of the game, which is to grow your town's population as high as possible, overcoming various obstacles like starvation, freezing, and malnutrition. The bigger your population gets, the more exciting the game becomes, because the threat of extinction is always lurking just around the corner. A single wrong decision, which may appear completely trivial at the time you make it, can spark a chain reaction that kills off your entire town.  You must carefully juggle dozens of factors to strike a balance between population growth and population management. Mass building houses in the early game may seem like a good path to explosive growth, but will inevitably cause mass starvation because you don't have enough food production.   Some of the game's features do seem a bit quirky, as your citizens follow a very strict set of rules. For example, a farmer goes to work on a farm; when he gets hungry he must go home and eat the food he stored there; if there's no food he'll go back to work, and starve while carrying the food he just harvested. While these features may seem nonsensical, they require you to plan your town development down to the last excruciating detail.  The biggest challenge of this game is to avoid making mistakes. As mentioned, a mistake usually won't become apparent until long after it's made. Trading away some of your stockpiled tools, for example, may seem like a good idea since you're not doing anything with them, until years later when your population suddenly expands and you face a tool shortage, which destroys your town's productivity, and naturally, leads to mass starvation.  The game also throws in a number of what I call Venus Flytrap features, ones that look too good to pass up, but are really invitations for disaster. Best example is Nomads, uneducated citizens without tools or cloths who offer to join your town and boost its population growth, which is after all what you want desparately as your natives are dying off from old age and not procreating fast enough. Aside from introducing diseases that may wipe off your town if you don't have enough hospitals ready, nomads will almost always start a butterfly effect that decimates your late game economy. A not-so-subtle, anti-immigrant sentiment from the developer, but oh well, nobody's perfect.   A golden moment of the game was when a 71 year old male Teacher shacks up with a 17 year old student, and when the latter turns 18, gives birth -- priceless. If only I took a screenshot.

Wow. I bought Banished this past weekend, and I'm hooked. The official description labels Banished as a city simulator, but it's much more basic than that. It's a colony simulator, and it makes you think about bare necessities rather than empire building. You start out with some basic supplies, but have to get everything else from your surroundings. It's a very laid-back, relaxing game--until you realize your firewood supply is low and winter is approaching, or you've used all of the available stone and can't build a bridge to the only place you have room for a quarry.   In the simplest terms, this is a management game. You have to balance a large set of priorities, moving people and resources to different functions throughout each year. But if you keep your people fed, clothed, housed, and healthy, you'll build your village into a thriving town, and eventually into a city.   At the low purchase price, this is a must-play for anyone who enjoys simulation games.

Banished is one of those rare titles that came along and completely hijacked my devout attention. It's something I think about even when I'm not playing it. Indeed, I catch myself pondering the most efficient building placements so that my hunters and gatherers don't have to travel too far for too long. I calculate and analyze ideal farm sizes to maximize their food production per farmer. I agonize over the realization that I must build new homes for my young citizens, or face a slow and certain decay through stagnation. I worry about the sustainability of my village. Knowing full well that stone, iron and coal are finite resources that once gone, are gone. Sure, I can plop mines and quarries but I cannot reclaim that terrain once they have been exhausted. Is that sustainable?  Again, it's rare a game that does this to me. Even the all mighty Civilization series rarely has me thinking this deeply about the game when I'm not playing it. The remarkable thing about this game is that despite everything I just said, it seems very uncomplicated at first. And in truth, it is pretty basic. Feed your people, provide them shelter, collect resources, EXPAND!   While that's all true. If you go about this process in a blundering or powergaming fashion, you'll do just fine. Until about your 25th year when you realize you've made a terrible mistake. That you've been repeating that terrible mistake each season. Your village is doomed, and there is little to nothing you can do about it. Assuming you realize your mistake at all.   Usually what happens, is you're suddenly faced with an unexplained catastrophe from a mistake you made as many as 10 seasons ago. This mistake could slowly lead to starvation, or even death by freezing when you run low on firewood and warm coats. You'll focus all your attention on resolving it. Yet, it's not until after your village dies and you walk away from the game that you analyze what went wrong. Thirty minutes later, you're back at the game vowing not to make the same mistake again.  The game features an option to toggle disasters like disease, fire, tornados, even pest infestations. Often, however, the biggest disaster to befall your village is you, the player. Will your banished villagers survive you? Get this game now, and you'll spend hours trying to find out.

I am not usually a huge fan of 'Worker Placement' games. This goes for both Board games (L'Harvre, Agricola, Stone age, etc.) and Video games (Towns being one of the biggest turn offs for me). So it was with a bit of hesitation that I opened the Store page to Banished, a higher resolution game of building a settlement from nearly scratch and making it survive. I purchased it yesterday, and for those people who want a short, quick review: TL;DR GET THIS GAME.  My play time right now is very limited. I have only clocked a few hours of this game, but I PLAN ON CLOCKING MORE. Please take this into consideration while reading this.  Starting from when I viewed the original trailer upon its release, I had hope that I may finally turn around my stroke of bad luck conscerning games like these. The game looks beautiful, runs smoothly even on somewhat dated systems, and the feel of it as you watch it run for the first time is very good. It may sound weird reading that last sentence, but it is really the only way I can explain it after seeing many games have a small lag time from when you see the title screen and when you can actually select anything from it.   The game comes with a tutorial that has a decent amount of depth to it, explaining and teaching you the basics of how to start up a small community of workers and labourers, and then does exactly what SHOULD happen after this stage: Leaves you alone. This game is set to be a strategic development game, so I would have been slightly put off if the tutorial held your hand the whole time while explaining when, why, and how you use each and every building. After learning the basic controls and solutions to problems players would experience in the first 15 minutes of game time, I found it pleasantly surprising how much of overall setting creation players get. Different seeds can be loaded, Resource availability, starting conditions, weather, even Disasters that may or may not be toggled (Cant wait till I get hit by my first tornado! :D) are all at the players fingertips right before s/he dives in to playing god.   During actual gameplay, the thing I like most is the freedom to do what you want, whether or not you will actually SURVIVE. My first town considsted of houses, a foresting agency, a fishing dock, and a mine. And by the 2nd or third year i had run out of food, had too many workers working the mine and dying of starvation, and realistically got my butt whooped by the in game Mother Nature after a half hour of game time. Starting again, I made a new town with more food production and less of other resources. Another failure, most of my food supplies died off during winter. Oh Well!  Time and Time again I have lost to this game, be it by starvation, population lock, disease, cold... And every time I lose I find myself renewed and refreshed, ready to start again and push my town further. The difficulty of the game is high, and a player will definetly need a good sense of planning and forethought to expand greatly, yet I think anyone who enjoyed games like Prison Architect, Roller Coaster Tycoon, Towns (Yikes!), and even the old Sim City games would easily fall in love with this piece.   So to end my Wall of Text review, I leave you with a Pro/Con list:  PRO  - Looks great  - Easy to navigate HUD and menus  - Freedom  - Plenty of replayability  - Lots of fun.  CON  - Difficulty is fairly high.  - (From what Ive read) Some events such as diseaased crops only give visual cues, like changed colors. Considering my play style, these might be hard to notice.

When I saw this game I was a little mixed. It sounded like it might be fun, but I wondered if it would maintain my interest. With no combat or any real meta goals besides simple survival and growth I feared it would be fun for a few hours then lose it's appeal. Add in that the price tag and I wanted to mull it over. I obviously decided to take the gamble and found myself extremely suprised and delighted. The game is deceptively simple. I say that because although the goal, gameplay, are straight foward enough, it hides a great deal of subtle complexity.   I remember my villagers starving to death the first couple times because I built two fishing piers. I figured food's done go enough. Wrong..... the amount of fish caught depends on the season, perhaps the proximity of one pier to the next also...... I'll have to tinker with that. In any case winter came fishing went kaput villagers quickly devoured the meager stockpile and that was all she wrote. That's only one of many small but meaningful complexities this game offers. Others hide you don't realize it was a mistake for a few years, then the light comes on as you see the error and must scramble to correct it before all you've worked for comes crashing down. If it takes you to long to figure it out the problem may well have snowballed beyond correction.   Because of it's seeming simplisity it is very relaxing, almost as though designed to lull one into a false sense of security. The lack of combat of any kind and focus upon survival seems to have been a very wise choice. No real bugs, game runs smooth on my old dual core processor. If I have any criticism it's minor. You can't choose your starting location on a map... period. Second regardless of the difficultity level you start each map has the same start location. The first is more a personal thing. The second however can make some maps, at hard difficulity at least, much harder than others. The same is probably true for the others to a degree. This lack of consistancy can be an annoyance, particularly when you start a map in a spot survey it and think there's no way, I'm gonna get screwed this way sooner or later. Then you have to go back and randomly gererate a new map. Getting the difficultity levels to be consistant from map probably by making the spawn different for each would put the final polish on an already excellent game. Here I'll grant I haven't played for to long yet and perhaps my skill or lack of it is giving me this illusion.  In the end if you enjoy a city builder, this one will not disappoint you. It will let you unwind, and at the same time keep your gears turning planning and considering each choice you make carefully. If your more combat oriented, sorry no soup for you.

Banished is a great experience with excellent pacing, a serene outdoorsy soundtrack, layered strategic town building gameplay, and a focused art style. I'm 20 hours into this game and I'm still finding new wrinkles.   Every game starts you out with a only a few families and a paltry amount of supplies. You command your settlers to transform a chunk or untouched wilderness into a successful town. You have to manage inventories of wood, stone, and iron resources, and make sure to make enough food and firewood to last the winter. You can expand your settlement's population by building houses for new families to move into.   The bigger your town gets, the more you can accomplish through whatever path you choose. Need food? You can farm crops, farm orchards, forage, fish, raise livestock, hunt, or trade. You can also mine coal and iron, quarry stone, and trade your resources for exotic seeds from distant settlements or a few chickens so you can start producing eggs. Choice is everywhere, and the game encourages you to try out new apporoaches. The level of strategic detail is impressive, but that doesn't mean the game is very difficult. The game does a great job of using the seasons to establish periods of surplus and times of famine. It's not a click-fest, success at the game is about following and anticipating these seasonal patterns.   The UI is really well done, because it's completely customizable. After you get of hang of it you'll find yourself sticking the info boxes around the edges of the screen like post it notes. You can have as many on the screen (or as few) as you want.  There's no combat but there are natural disasters, and you're really battling against time and nature. There's no story mode but the game does a good job of pulling you into your settler's lives by having nice touches like be able to build cemetaries and watching them fill in one by one (especailly in the early years, each death really hurts), buying a handful of cattle and seeing little calves the next spring, or having to deal with an infestation in your walnut orchards. The balance to this risk/reward gameplay allows you to tell your own stories.  It's not the most dazzling game graphically but the art is well done. The AI is pretty good too, with every citizen having different tasks depending on the job that you assign them. Banished might be too slow placed for some (though there is a fast-forward button), but for me this game scratches the same itch as any good sandbox game.

The Journal of Arde A Banished Tale  It started in the late spring, we were banished from our homes and sent out into the wilderness with nothing but potatoes, some hide coats, meager iron tools on our trusty wooden cart. We found a beautiful valley and started the town of Quentiss.  It was rough the first season; I started by building the local fishery so we could get a sustainable food supply. We built it right on Lake Quentiss at the mouth of Fiddlemagee Creek. The fishery supplied over a thousand fish per season (with four fishermen working) but we needed to have more food than just fish. So we build the Forestry service (to ensure we had enough logs to keep building) and next to it our first hunting lodge. The hunting lodge provided us with roughly 320 venison each season (With one hunter) and 9 leather so we could make hide coats (It gets cold in Quentiss in the winter). Across the street from the Forestry service I then built a hut for the gatherers. This is the ideal location for them to find berries, mushrooms, onions and roots. The Forestry service will ensure the forest is there providing logs, which attracts the deer for the hunters and ensures a stable growth of mushrooms and berries. Next door to the gatherer’s hut we build our first medical hut, the herbalist. Again, this was ideal because many of the needed herbs to keep us healthy are only found in the Forrest.  It was our first winter and we ran out of firewood as we were completing our first home in Quentiss. It was a very cold winter and the entire town, population of 12, all huddled in my home for warmth when they needed it. Next on my list to build was the woodcutter’s yard. By the end of late spring 2, we had firewood. Next I built the black smithy and tailor’s shop. We were running low on tools by late summer 2 and needed to have tools fast. The blacksmith has kept us in great shape since. We also have over 50 hide coats thanks to our wonderful tailor Matience. Unfortunately, we were running low on iron that we could find on the surface. We needed to build a mine.   I started work on the mine in the winter of 3, the problem we had was not enough stone to make the mine. So I spent the majority of year 3 & 4 gathering enough stone to build our iron mine. By late autumn of 6 the mine was open and we had a miner, Sandell, mining iron for our smithy and anything additional we needed to build. I gathered enough stone to build a second mine and built our first coal mine. This coal will allow us to upgrade our tools from iron to steel and get us more “bang for our buck” for our efforts. There is a plan to start work on our first quarry soon but we are still low on iron and a lot of iron is needed for our quarry.  As for the town as a whole, we are doing well. We have over 6,000 food, everyone is healthy and I am approaching 64 as we enter late autumn 9. I have given up building and have joined my husband Ailee in hunting. I like hunting as much as I liked building but it suits my tired body to hunt more than building.  Quentiss will need a graveyard soon as I feel my end nearing. My children, Ernellion & Jadence, will want to visit me after I am gone.  With peace and respect to those that follow me and read this, Arde  (P.S. If you like and enjoy other games like Sim City, Civilization, etc., this game is a good one to add to your library)

A decent civilization builder with a few hiccups.  I like this sort of game, it's a rewarding form of logistics management that, in this case, doesn't go overboard with endless details that detract instead of add to the game. Not many people want a Dwarf Fortress level of insanity and this manages a pretty reasonable balance.  You manage your population with housing, your food supply though everything from gathering to fishing to farming, your professions with tools and resources - it's diverse enough that the tutorial levels are very helpful. The tutorials do miss a couple of key things though, a good example is housing. I had initially assumed that people would breed and I'd be told when a new house was built but this isn't the case, the people wont reproduce if there isn't housing already waiting, by the time I found out the population had dropped to the point that there were too many sustainability problems to keep it going.  It's a surprisingly hard game to describe without sounding dull - but anyone who has played the genre before wont be surprised by anything found here. You have to balance expandsion with population with production capacity. Though another thing that could have used more of a mention is the trading. Trading is going to be very imporant to you - it's the only way to get animals to raise for one. It's how you get additional seeds for new crops as well and, probably most imporantly, stone.  Stone is probably my biggest complaint about this game. The earth may be made of it, but you're still going to run out. First problem is that there just isn't enough free stone on the surface. You can run out of everything within a reasonable distance long before you've got more than a modest village, compounded by the fact you should be building stone homes (stone homes are very important, they use a fraction of the lumber that wooden homes need to stay warm which can lead to a runaway fuel resource problem). There are quarries to be built but they require a lot of man-power which isn't feasable at the start and create a pit that is forever-after a useless patch of land once it runs dry. No, the only way to get stone (and eventually iron and coal as well since mines are also terrible) is to trade for it. Because of this, lumber seems to be the only truely infinite resource as long as you set aside land for forestry.  In addition to needing to trade for many of these things, you may also need 2-3 trading ports to get the trader you want appearing - they don't all carry the same types of items or the same selection of them each time. It does feel like an additional burden at a pretty early stage and could probably be fixed if quarries were simply a better choice. Make them slow to mine but an endless supply. Or limited but can reclaim the land.   That said, it shouldn't be so much as to scare you off the game, just a consideration to take into account. I may update this review in the future as my town grows but for now it's a recommendation and if you like they style of game, certainly something worth $20.

For so long now, RTS civilisation-building games either grow in to unwieldy behemoths that blow your mind (Anno 2070) or end up being join-the-dot type linear progressions that rarely end in any disaster other than 'oh, I've overspent again'. Banished takes civ-building to a whole new level and although it may be said that this game is relaxing to play, trust me - when the influenza strikes or the crop harvest fails, you will be sitting on the edge of your seat working out whether or not your people will survive.  The graphics are very pleasing with several types of housing to choose from and plenty of options for customising your village as it grows. With the added realism that you can't instantly remove structures (they have to be emptied then taken down by builders), extra thought needs to be made when placing them. It's amazing how much time you'll spend admiring your town as it grows.  I'm hoping this will be the start of things to come for Banished - there's scope for developing this game further with things like horse & cart transport, shops (luxury goods), currency, inter-city trading routes, even, dare I say it, defensive structures..?  The only thing lacking at the moment is some ability to control what merchants will bring - until your first visit from a merchant carrying livestock, for example, you can't order any. So after 31 years I still don't have any sheep, cows or chickens!  Still an amazing achievement for a single developer. Well done.

Overall: i'd give this game a 9/10 because of its excellent development, smooth ai, and lack of bugs.  the -1 for its repetative-feeling gameplay and lack of expansion. 9/10 would starve the school children all over again.

A peaceful life in exile, where you fantasize about starting over from the roots with just a hand full of comrades. This is what Banished offers as a town building simulation. Unlike it's competition, the challenge is in building a successful settlement and that all depends on micromanaging it's development while weathering the natural disasters of everyday medieval life. Those disasters include weather, the dangerous work of mining, and the great risks of fire, starvation, and disease. You'll likely abandon a few towns before you get this game right, but it's interesting to watch life unfold and it feels rewarding to succeed. It's a perfect game to sit down with a hot drink in the evenings and just mellow out to the calm rhythms of rustic life.

If you're into civilization-building (note the lack of a 'Sid Meier' or capital C in that phrase) game where you're essentially given a few families and a handful of resources and expected to make them thrive, then this game is for you. This isn't an AoE-type game, or even a Civilization-type game, insofar as there are no competing factions who will attack you. This is simply a population-focused survival game, and it's a pretty good one at that. I'm addicted.

Banished is a town-/village - building simulation with some refreshing new ideas, spiced up with some long-lost components which were not seen in this genre in the last few years.  Whatever you build or command, it has effects for at least several (playing minutes), if you don't fast forward the game speed constructing several buildings can easily take 15-20 minutes, based on their location and the materials needed. The workers have to clear the construction side from rocks and trees, have to bring the materials to the spot, and after all this the construction itself can begin. Since your workers are not only workers but also human, they got to do lunch-breaks, or go home to warmup from time to time if the temperature is low.  Banished simulates much more than many other games do, not only the single working processes of the workers, but also their life outside of work - getting food and firewood for their homes etc. is simulated for every individual villager (a thing the big 'Sim City' didn't manage to achieve).  Interesting fact: The game was crafted by one (ONE!) developer, this man kicked some big game studios' asses. The graphics aren't up-to-date of course, but they are still nice to look at, especially considerung ONE (i cannot stop to mention this) single person took care of all aspects of the game.  The game isn't perfect, but it is getting patched constantly and also will get mod-support soon, which will make the options and possible content explode.  If you are into the genre, dare to give this little gem a chance.  And please- eventhough it's DRM free, buy the game. People who invest that much of their freetime, taking the risk of all that time being lost because their game gets lost in the abyss of the videogame market, deserve it.

At it's heart, Banished is a simple game, but it is not easy. I have found it very difficult, at least at the start of a new game. It feels like, to me, getting everything almost perfect is critical to the survival of your people. Don't think I'm complaining, though! Getting a city to flourish is so incredibly satisfying, all the more so because it doesn't happen every time. There is a real sense of accomplishment watching your city grow.  However, it also means that problems you encounter are very difficult, sometimes impossible, to overcome. This game really teaches you that hindsight is 20/20. I would advise having a few different save files.  City management games can easily become tedious, but Banished has never felt so. There are definite stages. The founding of your city is, as I said above, the more difficult. Once your resources are sufficiently built up, you enter a stabilization phase, building population and expanding your city. The endgame is mostly trading for unrenewable resources, and can get a little monotonous, but it takes a while.  Banished is a truly beautiful game. The graphics are detailed without being overdone. I've never had lag or framerate issues. The soundtrack is similarly engaging, without being distracting.  The controls are a bit odd, but comfortable once you get used to them.   The Workshop is full of useful or fun mods, addressing balancing/peeves or creating new buildings.   All in all, 7.5/10.

They walk all the way across the map to get a tool when there are 500 in storage next to their own home. The list goes on and on. Because of this, I swear my citizens are suicidal.   I decided to not make it so easy for them! They'll die when I dang well decide they can die! In over 100 hours of game play I learned how to control my own population growth. I learned how to get people fed when they didn't want to eat. I learned how to keep them warm when they refused to wear a warm coat. I swear its like I'm raising a two year old. I need an airplane spoon mod that makes buzzing sounds when my food count is low!  In a weird twist of fate Banished casts your ally as your nemisis. If you enjoy an unforgiving challenge then I definitely recommend giving Banished a shot! If you think the ai should do all the work for you, steer clear.

Banished is one of those games you can spend hours living a comfortable village life, until in a few short moments everything goes horribly wrong. That simple concept is what makes this game great.  Banished is essentially a real time city builder game, where there is no real end goal, apart from loosely aiming for the in-game achievements. Set more or less in a medieval era, you must run your town, providing food, shelter, education, and a generally good quality of life to the citizens of your town. The core of the game is around balancing of resources, and making sure all essentials are kept in check. No food and citizens starve. No shelter and they freeze to death come winter. No healthcare and a plague could wipe out the populace. Now trust me when I tell you that when your resources become imbalanced and a shortage of something occurs, civilisation can fall very, very fast. This created tension, and when you are trying to push your town to the limits, avoiding this certain death can make the game so addictive, because in the back of your mind you know this game will be unforgiving if you make a mistake. The graphics are also tidy for a fairly simple game.  The brutality of this came can also be a downside however, as if you have spent a lot of time building a town for something to go wrong and it more or less dies out, rebuilding or starting from scratch could seem too much work for some players, so they might just give up there. Also there is limited replayablity here. Granted if you play this game to its potential it should get you 40+ hours (thats how long my main playthrough lasted, max pop ~980), but there's not too much incentive to play on after hitting the 900 population achievement, apart from going for a few of the more challenge like achievements.  Summary: Pros: -Simple concept -Addictive gameplay -Tidy graphics -Unforgiving gameplay creates tension  Cons: -Unforgiving gameplay could be frustrating -Somewhat limited replayability.  Final Verdict: 8.5/10 A very good game for a few dozen hours fun. Highly recommended.

Seven out of ten.  Banished is a slow paced town builder, set around the later middle ages of history, you and your available families build housing, storage, work places and try to create a flourishing city. The game has the pacing of molasses in winter, but at least initially it's good that it is that way as it gives you some time to work your way around things such as the menus, structure placement and citizen arrangements. You can also turn the game to 10x simulation speed if you're more impatient, but it's still a rather tedious game. Banished like all city builders echews combat for a peacful experience of struggling against different foes such as starvation and disease, space management. Foes that should not be underestimated as the intial contest for your life can be surprisingly difficult without proper attention. Once you have it figured out, it's quite quaintly enjoyable to build your blocks of houses, your city center with the town hall and market, and your pastures out in the fields. Banished though, does run a bit dry lacking a certain depth other city builders have achieved before it. You realize not long in that there simply isn't much to do over the first hurtle, and for a city builder, it's very lacking in the creative aesthetics that grant such enormous replayability to the other games of its kind.  Speaking of aesthetics, Banished wins me over just slightly in that regard. It's a rather pretty game in a quiet way. Watching the trees grow and fade over the seasons is just a touch of pleasantry that carries further than I might have thought. The buildings are well modeled and textured, though I found the villagers themselves to look a bit outdated. Water, and weather are nothing special but they do alright for the game, but the most disappointing feature is perhaps the single looping track that plays for the game. Okay, maybe not just the one, but the music while good is just lacking and gets a bit tired before you've even finished your first town (Discounting an early death as the hands of cruel nature).  In summary, Banished is a slow game and a good game, the problem being there just isn't enough of it. Worth it to pick up on a sale, perhaps not at full price.  Unofficially, the 'Colonial Charter' mod (Available through the workshop) adds some considerable value to the game, adding to nearly every aspect, perhaps even tripling the games content. Should you play the game, I heavily recommend trying this and other mods to add to the experience.

If you don't pay attention, things can go downhill fast, though. When that happens, it's hard (though not impossible) to recover.   I enjoy the graphics and the pleasant soundtrack. It's mostly soothing though. It would be nice to have a more urgent soundtrack when things start going downhill.  One gripe is that scrolling starts to sideshow when there's too much on screen (like lots of trees).   Another is that the trading ships are not very user friendly. You have to be patient if you want something specific from them (even if you 'order' it). Would also be nice if you could have more outside contact or interaction.   Recently added mod support is giving new life to the game by adding more resources and such. Some can be game breaking, some can be essential.  It would be nice if there were a storyline or more of an external impetus to do things. After you get past the 'are we going to starve next season or not' hump, there's not a whole lot I feel like I need to do but just grow bigger.  Also, the farmers could use some love. I find they start harvesting too late or are too inefficient. With the first snowfall often coming in late autumn, I lose a lot of crops. Some wheelbarrows or pulling in other helpers would be nice.  Overall a very pleasant and fun game. Super impressed that it was all done by one dude!

Who is this Game For? ================== Something that’s important to clarify with Banished is its classification as a city-builder. I don’t want to get too far into a discussion about semantics, but Banished is less of a true city builder in the same vein as the SimCity games, and more of a game about survival, expansion, and fighting against both the elements of nature, as well as the innate desire to progress. So while this game is for fans of ‘city-builders’, you need to understand its a little less builder and more of a survival and expansion city-builder.  Is it good? ================= This tension of total failure and destruction prevalent in the game keeps it exciting and engaging throughout. Knowing that at any time things could go wrong helps keep you on your toes, a constant reminder to take a moderate pace to expansion and think through every move. Banished utilizes this fear of failure to encourage you to find the best build orders and locations, and as well as adopt early population management strategies.  Does it have any problems? ======================== However, this is the crux of the game, and because the building mechanics are fairly stripped down to their bare essentials, the amount of enjoyment you extract from it will depend on whether or not the tension of survival clicks with you. Mods might be able to fix this for you, but your mileage may vary.   Final Thoughts! ==================== It’s a bit of a shame, because the core of Banished is so solid and rewards careful play, but it emphasizes a shallow expansion rather than one with any real substance. It challenges you to make your city bigger and bigger, but not necessarily better or more advanced. On the bright side, mod support has been promised in the future, and there is definitely a ton of potential for the community to pick up right where the developer left off, as well as expand in all sorts of wacky and fun directions.

Cons: -Very difficult to get started, i reccomend you look up a tutorial on how to get started. -Poor citizen AI system. the citizens are hard to control, and really do what they want, rather than what you want.  Overall: i would rate this game 8/10 1 point lost for the difficulty of starting, and another 1 point for the AI system. i would highly reccomend getting this game, its fun, challenging, and can be run on just about any computer you can get on.

Banished is a simple but very unforgiving game. More often than not, you won't know you made a mistake until it's too late. When you think your food reserves are enough, and that unforeseen baby boom happens and half your population ends up dying to hunger; it's unfortunate. You still have the surviving population to work with, and all the infastructure all ready to go for when you reach a higher population again. So you adapt your strategy, your food reserves are booming, and you once again have the high population. But now half your population dies again to old age, because majority of the surviving half from the previous catastrophe is much older than the new generations that followed. Ok... Adapt once more - focus on food, force the remaining population to baby boom. But once again, half your population dies. Why did they die this time? Not enough workforce between the old men and the toddlers to forge and distribute clothing, firewood, and stone houses(opposed to wood houses) for warmth.   You have to micromanage every factor, every citizen, every need for survival on a grand scale to build the ultimate utopia. Balance is the name of the game. Oddly enough, the only thing you don't have to worry about it being raided by bandits, invaded by neighboring settlements, or being eaten alive by wolves..  6/10 Would be higher if there were wolves.  Good for a cheap game. You can play for maybe an hour or two to pass the time. You'll inevitably drop it for quite some time afterwards, but every once in a while you might be inclined to give it another go. Cheers.

Where do I begin with Banished... With 120hrs on record, I haven't yet found a rhythm that can help me ascend to the greats and build a town that doesn't fall apart over a small span of time. One second I have more food than... Well, I have a lot of food, and lots of tools and resources and the works, the next minute my citizens are dying off and my town is up in metaphoric flames.  But I think that's the beauty of this game. I've played consistently on either easy/medium difficulty with disasters off, and I *still* can't exhaust the avenues of this game. There's such a learning curve, it's astounding. One day, perhaps when I have 300hrs on record, I'll graduate to turning on natural disaters, but we'll see... There are some complaints that there isn't much to this game, and I suppose when you look at the 'tech' or the buildings you can produce, that's correct, but the very fact that the game can be so simple in concept and yet so complex in its gameplay and its outcome - shows this game for the gem it really is.  I will admit that some of the negative reviews on here that point out the sometimes frustrating AI have a fair point, but every game has its issues, and I think these downfalls are more than made up for by the beautiful style, gameplay, and concept. Couple this with a beautiful and relaxing soundtrack and you have a game that you can never stay mad at when it kicks you in the teeth and wipes out your town, because it was all down in the picturesque landscape with a soothing track to keep you distracted. Another comment on here I think perfectly sums up why this game is worth every penny: you can leave this game for months/years at a time (I know, that's how I play it), but then you get the powerful urge/itch to play it, and nothing else will fill that void other than Banished. It is timeless, and I genuinely think it'll be classic in an age when we're looking at countless CoD sequels etc.  The playability is further boosted (if you could boost it any further) by the vast array of mods that open up the possibilities with more buildings and new mechanics. To name but a few, the mods by Redketchup will add at least another 500hrs to your gameplay.  So, I think for the mere price of £15, if you're thinking of getting Banished, think no more, buy it now!

Educated citizens are well worth it, but then maintaining all of the needs depends on how mnay working adults you have available.   Despite the amount of time I have on record I still get sucked into each new game I start. Added on the CC colonial mod addition and while the same basic needs are there, the variety of 'how' to meet those needs is significantly expanded upon and will allow the creation of your very own kingdom - if you can get everybody to survive and reproduce enough to have the citizen count for all the jobs.   Overall 10/10 highly recommended for anybody looking to enjoy a nice game of strategy and well worth the price.

Banished is what Banished is: A sandbox city-building Sim.  I wholely enjoyed this game. When I first picked it up, I didn't quite understand it. Amonst thinking I was doing things right, then takes me eyes off the tools for a moment and suddenly everyone is starving to death because they can't procure food fast enough due to the lack of tools. For awhile, I stopped playing thinking it was too hard and somewhat unfair (the land generation can be pretty cruel though).  After coming back to it again, learning a few tricks for myself, I saw the game a bit better. I managed to get a population of 1000+ people and getting about 70% of the achievements in 1 town. It was a really fun endeavor to reach that milestone for me.  The game has a few flaws of course. Workers living and working on opposite ends of the map, the tiniest hills are a pain in the butt, old people taking up living spaces from young couples who I need to make me more children but can't because the old people just don't die..., and then there is the lag. I have a pretty decent (not high end but more like medium end) rig but as the town gets bigger you WILL notice the lag, espically if you run at 10X speed. My 1000+ town caused so much lag at 10X speed that 5X speed ended up being faster... and even that was laggy. (8-11 fps VS 18-22 fps).  A few other issues pop up every now and then but in the long haul, the game is enjoyable with a good touch of challenge. It feels pretty rewarding to see the town grow. After that though the game loses replayability unless you are going for 100% achievements. (have fun btw.... 200 years is like 72 hours of running gameplay, twice as so considering the 10-20 fps you get with large towns).  I recommend the game, but only if it is on sale, honestly. It'll consume a good chunk of time until you've played it through like me.

So according to the sychophants on the forum, this game is now 'complete'. Let me tell you what you do in it: -Get banished from the kingdom of ?????? because you and the rest of the inhabitants did ???????? -Grow crops -Dig giant holes in the ground -Dig giant implied holes in the side of a mountain -Have a family of two hog the first and only house in the village so far while everyone else freezes outside -Occasionally have a trader row (just row. there's no land trade to speak of so even if you're in a relatively flat area where you'd expect caravans you just get one ♥♥♥♥ in a row boat) and try to barter some beans with you -Make a church so the already insanely happy people are even happier -Make a tavern so the already insanely happy people are even happier, and drunk -Make a hospital so everyone doesn't die from the chicken pox or something -Make a town hall so you can get pretty graphs and detailed accounts on how many potatoes Joe Blow has stuffed in his kitchen cupboard  And, well, that's pretty much it. Nothing wrong with that. It's a great start and I do enjoy what little there is. My issue comes with the 'completed' status and the fact I've seen maybe one update since I bought the game several months ago (which as far as I can tell was mostly just bugfixes). There's simply not enough game here.  Like I said, it's fun. I won't deny I enjoy watching my little lemming men run around, chop trees, and build roads so straight and villages so organized it'd send the Romans into a fit of envy. I'm just left wondering 'what about all the other stuff?' Where are the wild animals that tear lonely loggers to shreds if they venture too far from town? The bandits and barbarians who threaten to raze the city if they don't get a tribute of food? As far as I can tell getting banished from ?????? for ?????? (It really doesn't fill you in on any of this. I'm sure someone will pass it off as 'leaving it up to the player' but anyone with any idea of how to write things can tell you that's lazy writing) was more of a blessing than a curse, because if you don't make outright stupid decisions your village will be flourishing in a matter of years, and there's just not enough to threaten that prosperity. The winters mean less and less as your wooden buildings are turned to stone and your leather coats are lined with the wool from the sheep you traded six trillion beans for. Outbreaks are handled quickly and efficiently by the magical witch doctor that just rubs some plants on the afflicted's face until they're suddenly better. The only thing that will eventually theoretically threaten your village (assuming you play this long before getting bored) is running out of room for graveyards from all the people that eventually die from old age, and I'm sure even that could be avoided by keeping everyone happy enough they don't care Old Man Jenkins's carcass was thrown into the woods for the nonexistent wolves to tear apart. I'm not really angry. I'm just disappointed. There's too little game here where there should be, and I'm finding myself questioning the legitimacy of its 'completedness'. I'm sure I'll be Not Helpfulled into oblivion by the raving drones that insist it was money well spent and can't take a lick of criticism, but all I can say is welcome to the reviews section, kids.

Banished is a strange game. It has a great aesthetic - especially in the winter - that is compelling enough to keep you coming back for more. There's nothing quite like the sight of your little village covered in a blanket of snow, smoke billowing out of every chimney. Aesthetic, however, isn't really enough to hold your focus for too long. Other reviews go into great detail about what you need to do to succeed but it can be summed up in two parts - gather resources and breed.   At first this can be a fun balancing act to play out. Too much breeding and you're resources will start to dry up fast, too little and you'll struggle to get those resources quick enough to sustain your population much less grow it. Once you find the happy medium that works for your village you can plug along fairly well, at least for a while. Banished is big on throwing natural disasters at you - or at least it was for me. In three consecutive playthroughs I had things moving along wonderfully when a tornado would touch down and level my town. My population was decimated and despite my best efforts all three towns eventually died out.   Overall, that's the issue with Banished. It's not so much a city builder so much as it's a city survival game. The AI doesn't help, either, as citizens of your town can be frustratingly foolish. More than once I watched a citizen wander into the forest looking for food only to starve to death out in the wilderness when there was a surplus of food sitting in the barn for them. An even worse example for you: I once had a town starve to death despite it being flushed with productive farms. Over half of my population were farmers, herdsman, and fishermen and they still somehow found a way to starve to death, all of them. There's nothing more bleak and yet ironic than watching a farmer harvest his crops, the only person residing in a town of once over 50, slowly starving to death. And rest assured, the farmer died just like all of his friends and family, starving to death in the middle of his field.Throw a tornado or fire in on top of that, leveling a perfectly good town in its prime, and the game can become painfully frustrating.   Banished is not a bad game but like most of the reviews on here, I'll tell you the truth - there's not a lot to it. You can build a sprawling metropolis if you want but there's nothing to do with it. There's no end-game, nothing to strive for beyond trying to surive as long as possible. You can't go out and get revenge on the town that kicked out your founders or even interact with other villages. Your only contact to the outside world are solitary traders, the only evidence of life outside of your village. This game could be easily be cast as settling another planet for the first time, it's that empty. If you can get it on sale for cheap, buy it. It is fun at first and, like I said, can be beautiful in a quaint, colonial kind of way. Just understand that after a while it will lose its spice.

Once you attain a population of about 300 or more, there simply is no reason to play the game any longer. There needs to be a 'next-level' for players, after they've built past the survival stage, where grander buildings, regional conflicts (perhaps building an army for defense), or new villager specialist professions become available. However, If you want a more enjoyable long-lasting game, buy Sim City 4. It's also only around $20.00 and is far superior to this game.

Alright, so first and foremost, the game IS pretty interesting and has a great concept. It's basically a really neat city builder kind of game set in a pretty simple medieval-esque setting, no combat, no deeper overlaying faction mechanics, diplomacy, nada, just survival in the wilderness, and making your little halmet grow. And that's really cool and great and all -- when you have everything perfectly and tediously set up beforehand.  See, the problem is, that as your town starts growing, your citizens AI begins to act haywire.  Even getting them to their very best, ie issuing them warm coats, giving them proper education, making sure they are healthy and well fed, and clear stone paths to their general work areas, they will still get stuck in these asinine chain of actions that can ultimately kill your town or make simple instructions take up towards a while year.  Like take a builder for example. You instruct your builders to build say, a fishing dock, relatively nearby the town, set that junk to be prioritized (which is a function that does virtually nothing).  The builder will (not neccesarily in this order, and also sometimes several times until completion): 1) Go pick up stones from the entirely opposite end of the village to store in the stockpile 2) Go pick up food twice 3) Walk to the construction site, store some building materials, and do something entirely different 4) Go visit the herbalist 20 times 5) Walk to the construction site, and then decide to walk all the way back home because he feels cold 6) Walk to the construction site, build 1%, and then go do something else 7) Go build 3 tiles of road somewhere else 8) Go visit the herbalist, again  And this sort of thing applies to any profession that has the citizen walking anywhere, so imagine what a sucker I felt like seeing my 15 laborers ignore cutting down the prioritized tree farm for a whole year and making my town freeze to death twice.  Like damn man, I used to play Dwarf Fortress of all games, so I really do want to consider myself to be patient with strange AI behavior, but this game just gets absurd with that sometimes, to the point where it can be completely game breaking.  A lot of people talk about how the game is hard too. And sure, it can be a bit of a challenge early on while you set everything up, but once you are starting to stabilize things you kinda start to get the impression that a large part of the 'difficulty' is actually related to how terrible the AI can be at doing their tasks.  So look, it's a pretty sweet game overall, so by all means do buy it and try it out. Just be prepared to savescum and get endlessly frustrated by your citizens AI a bunch.

Intro  The game type is not only sandbox, but a  full  sandbox game: indeed it lacks any type (really any type) of goal. The game genre is a strategic medieval city management with stunning graphics and it has (maybe) the better season system I've ever seen.   Pros  - 3D graphic and visuals are wonderful; - music is good also if there are just three or four songs and that's it; - season system is really realistic and well represented into the game; - in the first game the morale will be destroyed by death of a family member and the cemetery is used also to replenish it: it's totally realistic; - trade is another realistic thing: to me is ok but for someone could be too much 'real'.   Cons  - total lacking of plot and goals: just survive in a random generated land; - it gets repetitive: any scenario will force you to find the same configuration of buildings to survive (i.e.: forester+gatherer will be the first of your problems in any scenario also with food buildings). The total absence of research and progression in time will render the game just more repetitive: it's merely the same building after one hour of play and the same after twenty; - no campaign and no friend or enemies to interact with anyway no interaction at all with anyone; - after you've decided a scenario is done (because resource is limited or because you're satisfied or because simply you've no more building space) the only strong reason to play another one is a passion for the Steam achievements.   Conclusion  Banished with some more attention and variety could've reached the Olympus of the strategy games. Unfortunately the game is really survive and that's all. Apart from that this game reminds me the first in The Settlers serie: ok in 1993 graphics are not like that :) but the concept is the same. I abandoned The Settlers at the sixth level because I found it repetitive: any new scenario brought more or less the same challenges but at least they are masked with some interaction with enemies and a progression in difficulty. In Banished I felt the same sensation... at the first scenario: for me it's inconceivable to have the same let's say configuration at the first hour and at the tenth. Nothing evolves in Banished.  So to appreciate or not this game depends on the type of player you're: I have limited time to play, I love plot, character/condition evolution, research, development and of course strategy. If you're like me, then you could find this game frustrating and maybe found something better to invest the limited time in. If you have plenty of time to invest in playing and you cannot sleep until you've obtained every Steam achievement in the universe, then definitely Banished it's for ya ;)

To start of: Banished is a city builder type of game in the same vein as Age of Mythology, Anno series, The Settlers, Children of the Nile, ect. But how the game differs is in its design philosophy: Namely the game isn't so much about upgrading your settlements like in many of the aforementioned game and combat doesn't even exist at all.  This is where the greatest enemy is the environment itself. Unless you play on a very easy setting - you will be controlling a small group of people who settle in a quite cold biome resembling the northen europe/russia climate which means; very harsh winters and a single harvesting opportunity in autumn.  The game takes place in medieval times - they live in relatively poorly insulated tree houses which require fuel to sustain heat during the winter. The fuel is either coal dug from mines or firewood chopped from regular lumber. To keep this resource in a steady supply thereforth becomes a priority.  The other challenge is farming. In most other city builders you can sustain your population with relatively low amounts of farmers or less amount of effort, more in vein with the modern farming revolution that allows more farming with less manpower. In this game however you need to dedicate at the absolute minimum 50% of your population to gathering food from different sources. This becomes a rather important issue throughout the whole game regardless of your population size. Since farmlands take up a lot of space, it presents an interesting dilemma for how you're supposed to plan your village. It doesn't work very well to try and plan like a city where farms are at the edges of society. Instead they need to be an integral part of where you put your housing for your people. If you think this is boring to read about - then you might not like this game. It is very important part of the game sadly that the game is very unforgiving about. Sometimes famines happen due to a overconsumtion of a few families, which makes food gathering so very important and even a relatively short famine has devestating effects that are nigh impossible to stop - often reducing your population with 75% which in turn makes it harder to gather food.  When you get the food situation under control - you then need to make sure that your villagers can surivive the winter. Since climate gets quite cold during the winter you need to make sure that they have enough fuel. Thankfully this isn't as big an issue sometimes and can be helped in a number of more ways than farming. For example; in addition to providing more fuel you can also provide coats of leather, wool or both (which you aquire from livestock and hunting). You can also upgrade your houses from wooden houses to stone houses. Stone being a more difficult material to gather and requiring more manpower makes this largely a very late game thing. Especially when the woodcutters start to run out of convenient space and any reduction in your citizens needs are incredibly helpful. The benefits of building stone houses early exists but are ultimately rather small to begin with.  This sort of makes winter an easy thing to deal with for anyone knowing what they're doing, and really - these are the only two needs for the citiziens to be satisfied. There are two other needs which are health and happiness but from what I've played - and I haven't played a lot: I haven't seen any need for satisfying health or happiness. My citizens live up until the 70 ages which in my opinion sounds like a massive lot in those times. Especially considering that most age related diseases starts at 40 - 50 years of age and only escalates. With that in mind I think that the game's idea of people's life expectancy is a bit unrealistic.  Happiness is satisfied in two ways: Religion and Drinking. You can build chapels and taverns in the village where the population gathers to pray or drink their problems away. But there's no interesting dynamic to them. Everybody in the village seem to be able to become a member of a church, but they don't seen to take any time off to really go and pray. But I don't know if it's the same with taverns.  Health is satisfied in two ways too. You can keep your citizens healthy through a varied diet so growing different corps has a benefit in that regard. And there's also a herbalist building which gathers herms in 'ancient forests' which increases health as well. Since the game doesn't seen to have any mechanics of sickness (of exclusion of diseases which are not cured by herbalists but by doctors in a hospital), the importances of placing herbalists seem to be more trouble than it's worth.  Diseases like I mentioned before are another aspects of the game: Namely catastrophies. These events are either fires or diseases. These seem to happen very rarely with low populations so again - it's a late game thing, but they're easy to solve. In the case of disease: Putting down a hospital or two makes it so that all sick people gathers there and are kept from the rest of your healthy population. Often they even get cured there somehow and can later return to the workforce with a surprisingly low amount of consequences. You combat fires by placing out wells around the town for your citizens to pull water from. Since I never have experienced a fire - I cannot even tell how that mechanic work.   So to summarize: This is a game with a bunch of elements, that it tries to keep realistic. You mostly sit and wait for your workers to grow crops, grow the population, put down more places where crops are supposed to grow, waiting for them to gather materials (which I forgot to mention, but it's takes a long time and requires a lot of manpower). Sadly the game just isn't very fun. There are no interesting dynamics in play here. Yes people need to eat, yes people need to be kept warm. These are good basic mechanics, but what about town events or entertainment or traveling minstrels or raiders? The village seem so very isolated and it makes the game seem so much more barebones than its competitors. I think the game could have used some more time to think up better dynamics because ultimately it's boring to watch people strolling around and collecting stuff and waiting for opportunities to expand. This makes the player a slave to the game instead of the other way around which I think it should be. I like city builders a lot but this is in my opinion a poor one. You might still like it thanks to its difficulty but for me it was not a lot that I felt was worth going through the difficulty to make it feel rewarding enough - thereforth I don't recommend this game.

On the one hand it's a good game that will provide several hours of enjoyment. On the other hand there's not much challenge once you “figure it out” and so the replay-ability is not there. Overall, I might think $10 justifiable if it were a final game (and give it a different rating then), but as it's not complete yet I think it's overpriced considering what you get. If you are considering this purchase, I would say wait until a 'final' version is released and hopefully some more features will have been added to justify the cost (and hopefully the price won't go up).  The Good  What Banished does well, it does really well. It is quick to learn and much of it is very intuitive. Most of what you need to know is right in the tutorials which don't suck up your time but leave you feeling like you are ready to tackle the world.  The interface is easy to use and you won't find yourself going from window to window trying to figure out what just happened and why. There are information windows, but these can be kept open and put out of the way so that “the game” is what's going on in your city, not how goo you are at micro managing.  The graphics are great and large cities look amazing. I would love to be able to zoom in more and maybe follow a person around from their perspective, but what is there is really good. One bit that I found wasn't great was the lakes and rivers which (on some maps especially) when you zoom out far enough looked kinda like someone used a pain tool to draw them on the map. The solution, of course, is to not zoom out too far.  Once you get going on a city you do tend to loose yourself in the game, at least for the first 200 citizens. The whole “just one more turn” effect applies to this game (even though it's not turn based) until you reach larger sizes. It's easy to play the same way a good wine is easy to taste. (Who am I kidding, I'll drink any wine.)  The Bad  Banished is simple to learn and easy to play because it's an easy, simple game. Yes, you will have a challenge on your hands to figure out the secret to starting a successful city without losing settlers, but once you figure that out there's not much left. (I should note that I've never played anything except the hardest difficulty.) This is NOT Dwarf Fortress (complex and hard to play), but it is also not Sim City (complex but easy to play).  The list of challenges in the game include:  (1) Not dying that first year (or two). Once you figure out the trick this is no longer an issue. (2) Surviving minor disasters. People (and crops) die, get used to it...and plan for it. (3) Surviving major disasters. Few and far between in the games I've played, but having a large enough stock of everything seems to make this more of a hassle than a game-changer (with the notable exception of fires). (4) Build big and accomplish some challenges (things like population levels, # of buildings of certain type, etc). These are not in-game challenges and they don't have in-game rewards (that I've noticed), so there's not much point to them except to say you've done them.  The lack of challenges means that the game suffers in the replay-ability aspect and fails to hold attention beyond managing to create a large city (which is easy, just time consuming).  There is also a distinct lack of variety in the game. This can be seen in both the graphics (well done, just not many different homes, bridges, or wildlife as examples) and the basic resources (logs, stone, and iron metal – no different types of these things, that's it – oh, and coal which is all but useless). You can't plant trees along the paths or build a monument to yourself in the centre of town. The one exception is crops – there are many different types here which can be used to make a city look interesting (they are really not needed to survive, or even thrive, at all).  The lack of variety means that every city will look and feel about the same and there's no way to put your own signature on any given map. You will be able to mod the game eventually, but that seems like it's up to the players to make it a good game, which I have never bought into.  Final Thought  So, on one hand I *do* recommend the game because it's well done and for the first few tries you will have great fun (for me that was about 20 hours). On the other hand I *don't* recommend the game because there's just not enough there to justify the cost. However, if more features are added or if you see this game on sale...

This game has a lot to offer, and... I want to like it. I really do. But I can't.  It offers a simple 'village builder,' where you can lay out your town as you please - no need to worry about setting up inefficient trade routes between islands (here's looking at you, Anno) or spamming area-of-effect buildings (SimCity) throughout the map. You build what's needed (a quarry to cut stone out of the ground after you've scavenged everything from the surface, for example), scale appropriately (farms to produce food as more families populate your town, for example), and you should be good-to-go.  Alas, it is not so. The AI - your townspeople - will ruin the experience of building a settlement for you.   Simply put, the moves your AI townfolk will make are terribly inefficient bordering on the outright nonsensical. Once your town seems to reach a certain threshold (greatly exacerbated in the 'mountains' style maps, where small pockets of population separated by terrain features dot the terrain), your workers will simply scramble in random patterns while resources go uncollected, buildings lay incomplete, and food goes to waste.  Don't count on workers to live near their place of employment - instead, count on workers to live in a random pattern, where they'll necessarily need to run all the way across town to get to work, only to find themselves exhausted at the end of the journey, turning around to get something to eat or warm up at the house - while the aforementioned projects lay idle. Your townspeople will, despite having plenty of food or resources stored for use, starve themselves for lack of time to collect and use those resources as they run clear across the expanse of whatever settlement they live in...   Unless you're extremely tedious in building housing immediately prior to putting a new production site down - something that's not feasible unless you're spending a ton of time deliberately planning every move versus 'going with the flow' of managing input/output as resources are built up or dwindle under the strain of new citizens - you'll simply watch your town(speople) self-destruct under the weight of the AI's ignorance. Not for lack of resources, mind you. Just that they're too stupid to locate closer to home, even if you intend for the queue to line up that way.   Ultimately, this wrecks the game and, unfortunately, I cannot recommend.

Banished is... clean. Too clean, really. A city-building and resource management game reminiscent of Dwarf Fortress with a pretty GUI and a heavy antibacterial wipedown, Banished puts you in charge of a band of serfs, throws you into the wilderness, and tasks you with gathering resources from the environment in order to build a functioning settlement. Wood, stone, and iron are necessary for building structures. Tools and education keep your peons productive, food and clothing and shelter keep them healthy, and liquor, church, and corpse disposal keep them sane. Provide all of the above and your population will grow into a happy, healthy ant farm.  The problems lie in how basic and generic the game is. There are only a couple dozen structures to build, and with no options or upgrades for any of them, there's very little strategy to it; simply build everything as you can afford it, and make sure it's all densely packed with easy road access and ample wells around in case a fire breaks out. The environment consists of water, ground, and mountain tiles, with no unique resources or features to break up the monotony. Your citizens have no personalities, few unique traits, and cannot even be differentiated by skill - they can be Educated or Uneducated (which provides a slight penalty to all job performances), and everyone wields the same omnitools for all jobs. If the game provided the player with some concrete goals to aspire to, or made the world a bit more antagonizing, and made the losses from the few disasters it offers a bit more devastating, then maybe there'd be some fun here, but it's a pure sandbox game whose only goals are the Steam achievements, all of which involve playing for obscene amounts of time and stockpiling useless luxuries. It could be improved immensely with the addition of silly cosmetic buildings and structures, or some kind of lore or storyline to add flavor, but there's nothing of the sort.  I can appreciate what Shining Rock Software was trying to do here, but Banished just doesn't take any chances and isn't anywhere near being feature-ful enough to maintain interest. It's a nice demo, but let me know when you've got the rest of the game ready.

I'd heard the game was tough and unforgiving, but it's absolutely ridiculous. Before you play, you have to  turn the disasters off ; they break the game. Let me explain:  Tools are a  very  important resource in the game. Without them, your civilians  can't build things.   Naturally, when a tornado or a fire destroys your storage barn, you're going to have to rebuild it- right? Well, that's the thing- you can't. When your storage barn is destroyed, absolutely everything inside it is  apparently completely unsalvageable  also destroyed. It all disappears; food, tools- everything. Without tools, you can't rebuild another barn. Without a barn, you can't store food, without food, your civilians die in minutes, and that's it. Game over. I even tried building an  extra  storage barn on the other side of town, to spread my resources, but the game doesn't let you control what goes into your storage barns, so my civilians did not use my emergency storage barn, and it just sat there, empty.  You can store tools in your trading post, but- get this- the only way your civilians can access them is if they are moving the tools TO A STORAGE BARN! So the tools just sit there in crates, unused, even though you desperately need to use them.   There is literally nothing you can do to prevent even a perfect town from being completely wiped out within seconds by a spontaneous tornado, at any given moment. It's the most ridiculous, out-of-your-hands 'game-over' you'll ever experience. The random disasters should be there to set you back, not to break the game completely. I'm amazed that this could be overlooked by an otherwise very talented developer.  tl;dr: The game forces you to put all your eggs in one basket, and then stomps the ♥♥♥♥ out of the basket, and all you can do is watch, grief stricken. Otherwise, it's a great game. If they fixed this bug, then I'd give it 8/10, but until then, it's a 5/10.
