I came into this game with great expectations. I love civilization-building games like this, and the depth that this game offered enticed me to spend on its relatively low price. My computer meets all the specs, but the game crashed four times after fifteen to twenty minutes of game time each time I tried to play. In the short time that I was able to play, however, there was not a really easy-to-follow tutorial either, which is needed for a game of this depth. Could it be a great game if it ran and if the tutorial was more clear: yes. Can I recommend it based on my experience: absolutely not.

I have been a long-time lover of city-builders, and I was very excited to play Banished, but upon playing it... I found it very lacking.   My biggest problems are with the mechanics, which are the most important ones in a game like this. The whole premise is that you need to build a suitable village for a group of people who were ( assumably) banished. You start out with some basic food, tools and clothes, and then you are on your own.   The initial set-up is challenging. I had to do a lot of juggling with the jobs that my villagers occupied, because some jobs would stall or pause in certain seasons or without enough resources. This is not necessarily bad, but with the mechanics of Banished, this becomes a down-right nightmare. Say I have need of food, and I assign one of my miners to become a fisherman instead. Randomly, one of the miners will be chosen to fish - no matter the location of his house. So this man will spend far too much time walking to his destination to work, and he is only effective when he works at the location I assigned him.   The food crisis is over, and I assign one of my fishermen to be a miner... And it is not the same man i had as a miner previously.  In the end, this means that nobody lives near their jobs, and that their effectivity is greatly reduced. With perfect play, this can all be prevented, but that brings me to the next point;   When you have everything settled...... there is nothing to do.  There is no king you need to keep happy, there are no politics of any kind. Buildings always have a direct function, and so they never take more than half a day to build, unless you do not have the materials. When everything was going well I found myself bored, but as soon as something got out of hand, there was almost no way to effectively turn it back around without massive losses.   There are tons of small aggravating things in this game; - If you build too many houses, the people will stop marrying and making babies, because each person occupying a house.  - If you stop building houses, you will get the problem that people will ALSO stop making babies, because there is no more room in their house for a child.  - Mines and quarries are so ineffective that they are downright useless, and the few stone/iron resources given on the map run out quickly -There is little to no character to the townspeople, and there is not even a line of text for them to show unhappiness with. They only have stars to show their happiness, which can be fixed by a church or a bar.  -Some buildings need to be in remote locations, but the people that work at them do not live in these buildings, forcing them to walk a far way and waste valuable working time.   I had very high hopes for this game, but compared to the citybuilders I was used to by the time I got this game, it was a big disappointment.   On a more positive note; the music and visuals are very enjoyable. When played casually on the easy difficulty, I found it a very good game to relax with, and it was satisfying to see the farmers harvest their crop.  I do not recommend it for people that were looking for a citybuilder like Ceasar 3 or Children of the NIle, but if you want to have a relaxing time building a small village with bland villagers, this game is good.

This game starts out fun, and then it gets annoying. It is the little things that make this game unplayable. Mainly how people starve and freeze to death all the time.  When you think you are doing well on food, think again, because in a minute you will miraculously having starving citizens and have no idea why. I wish the game showed who wasn’t producing good and who is so you can focus on high yield food options. *People freeze because they are too stupid to occupy one house to stay warm. Everyone wants to sit in their own house having to heat a single house for one person instead of a few houses filled with a couple people. This should be reworked. Also the fact people go through coats in a few years. I have had the same coat for over 10 years and it is fine. People freeze outside too fast. *People are just stupid. They go far away to chop down a tree, then don't even bring back the materials with them.  They also have too many kids, especially when your adults are starving, they selfishly have kids to have more mouths to feed. There should be a Governor after you build the federal building to tell the people to stop having kids. Or you should be able to be given the option to kill off older people or kids to preserve the community as a whole. On the other hand when your people are in desperate need of kids, they seem to not produce. Again, the government would help force this.  *People are also too dumb to move into houses close to where they work. I know everyone wants their own house, but when things are tough, people need to move into houses close to work, even if they are occupied by others, for the greater picture. Also farmers need to learn to harvest their entire crop before dropping off harvested portions. My farmers end up harvesting 1/16th of their crop, then packing it up to go take it to the storage. Harvest the entire thing and let the Laborer do the picking up. The farmer can help after his whole field is done being harvested. This would prevent 1/2 of the field getting wasted to winter coming too soon when he is busy transporting the food.  This game sadly, is only playable on a level of fun when it is heavly modded. The way it is by itself becomes unplayable, and unfun very fast.

On the surface this seems like a great game, but that's as far as it goes. Beneath the veneer of the visually appealing graphics and simplistic design you think you can see a city builder with a survivalist inspired challenge. In reality, the games poor AI design and unrealistically frustrating features inspire the entirety of the challenge. Good game to paddle with for a few hours, and explore the buildings; but once the honeymoon wears off you'll find you will close it angrily and never open.  If you can't see where I am comming from with the AI, here's a few things that I found myself annoyed at: - Villagers dying of starvation whilst holding food - Villagers ignoring buildings that are not connected by land mass but only by bridge. - Animals walking through the rivers and wandering through mountains (Not really that annoying, just rings of poor code) - Villagers constantly using coal when there is a huge coal shortage and tool shortage. - Villagers spend most of their times walking around on unrelated tasks to their purpose. (Is not solved by better building placement beacause they seem to prefer certain buildings over proximity)   I could go on and on about the AI, but I've made my point. Mind you, this will only really affect you right at the start or 100 pop in, when said issues will certaintly starve off half your town until food supply can cope, and rinse and repeat. A city builder and manager is entirely focused on having a decent AI, and if it's not there: the entire game will suffer tremendously.
